title: Alvarado Score for Acute Appendicitis
description: Predicts likelihood of acute appendicitis based on clinical symptoms, signs, and laboratory findings. Uses the MANTRELS mnemonic to assess 8 clinical factors for diagnosis of appendicitis.

parameters.name: migration_to_rlq
parameters.description: Migration of pain to the right lower quadrant (right iliac fossa)

parameters.name: tenderness_rlq
parameters.description: Tenderness in the right lower quadrant (right iliac fossa)

parameters.name: rebound_tenderness
parameters.description: Rebound tenderness or indirect signs (Roving sign, Dunphy sign, Markle test, percussion tenderness)

ranges.interpretation: Low probability of appendicitis (1-6% risk). Consider discharge with close follow-up. No further imaging typically needed.
Intermediate probability of appendicitis (15-25% risk). Consider observation, serial exams, or imaging (CT scan). Surgical consultation may be warranted.
High probability of appendicitis (75-85% risk). Strong indication for surgical consultation and likely appendectomy. Consider expedited surgical evaluation.
Very high probability of appendicitis (>90% risk). Very strong indication for immediate surgical consultation and appendectomy. Imaging may delay necessary surgery.

references: Alvarado A. A practical score for the early diagnosis of acute appendicitis. Ann Emerg Med. 1986 May;15(5):557-64. PMID: 3963537.
Alvarado A. How to improve the clinical diagnosis of acute appendicitis in resource limited settings. World J Emerg Surg. 2016 Apr 26;11:16. PMID: 27123036.

Coleman JJ, Carr BW, Rogers T, et al. The Alvarado score should be used to reduce emergency department length of stay and CT use in select patients with abdominal pain. J Trauma Acute Care Surg. 2018;84(6):946-950.
formula: Migration (1) + Anorexia (1) + Nausea/Vomiting (1) + Tenderness RLQ (2) + Rebound tenderness (1) + Elevated temperature (1) + Leukocytosis (2) + Left shift (1) = 0-10 points
notes: The MANTRELS mnemonic helps remember the 8 components: Migration, Anorexia, Nausea/vomiting, Tenderness in RLQ, Rebound tenderness, Elevated temperature, Leukocytosis, Left Shift
Tenderness in RLQ and leukocytosis are weighted more heavily (2 points each) as they are the most important predictive factors
The score performs better in men and children than in women of childbearing age due to higher false-positive rate in women
Originally developed as a rule-out tool for low scores (<4) and rule-in tool for high scores (>6)
A score of 5-6 is compatible with appendicitis diagnosis, 7-8 indicates probable appendicitis, and 9-10 indicates very probable appendicitis
